conversations.content: The Lady and the Boar: Part One
Long ago, before Lady Amaterasu and the shogun ruled the land, Hinomoto was a country at war.
Hinomoto was split into several provinces that fought amongst themselves, each claiming they would be the one to finally unify the land into a single country.
One such province was ruled by a lord with a young daughter. He was a kind and generous man, and the people loved both him and his daughter without reservation.
One day, a hunter appeared and gifted the lord and his daughter with a freshly trapped boar. He then bade them kill it and eat it that very night.
The lord was overjoyed, but the daughter looked upon the terrified animal with great pity.
Before the boar could be killed, the daughter took it to the foot of the mountains and released it back into the wild.
The boar rejoiced at its freedom, and made a promise to the girl: ＂If ever you are in dire straits,＂ it said, ＂I will come to your aid.＂
The daughter simply smiled in return before shooing the animal away.
Thankful for the girl's kindness, the boar returned to its happy life deep in the mountains.
Several years passed, and the little girl grew into a fine young woman. She had utterly forgotten the promise the boar made to her all those many years ago.
One day, a powerful neighboring province declared war on the girl's land.
She knew they could not win a war, so the woman donned a strange set of armor and made her way to Marishiten—a dragon said to be in possession of great power.
＂Mighty Marishiten!＂ cried the girl when she finally found the dragon. ＂Save our land, I beg of you!＂
Marishiten smiled before replying. ＂I'll help you...but only if you defeat me in combat. And if you lose, your life will be forfeit to me.＂
The Lady and the Boar: Part Two
When a young woman sought help from Marishiten in order to save her land from an attacking province, the dragon presented her with a life-or-death challenge.
＂If you defeat me,＂ said the dragon, ＂I'll save your land. But if I win, I get your life. Don't think too long about this, now; it's the best deal you're gonna get.＂
The young woman was at a loss. Though she was clad in armor, she had never so much as swung a sword in her life—much less battled with a dragon.
However, she knew it was the only chance for her people, so she steeled her resolve and accepted the dragon's challenge.
Marishiten cackled and raised her sword high, while the terrified woman held her own weapon in front of her in a trembling grasp.
The sharp clang of metal on metal rang out, and the woman's sword went sailing through the air.
Devastated, the woman sank to her knees, closed her eyes, and waited for the final blow to fall.
But the fatal strike never came. After what seemed an eternity, the woman finally opened her eyes to see a boar standing between herself and the dragon.
＂Lady Marishiten!＂ cried the boar. ＂Pray spare this human's life, as she once saved mine when I had been captured by others of her kind!＂
The woman was bewildered, for she had forgotten how she saved the boar as a child. Then the animal went over to the woman and used its snout to push her to her feet.
＂I promised I would be there to help you in dark times, did I not?＂ said the boar. ＂Now go! Flee while you can! I will explain all to the dragon.＂
At that moment, the woman's memories of the boar came crashing back with the force of a wave, and she fell back to her knees and hugged the boar fiercely.
Marishiten watched this for a moment before letting out a deep sigh. ＂You shoulda told me this earlier, boar,＂ she said. ＂I almost took the head off your savior there!＂
＂His...savior?＂ asked the woman. ＂Yeah,＂ responded Marishiten. ＂That boar is my servant, and you saved his life. So not only will I spare you, I'm actually gonna do you a favor.＂
＂I'll save your land and people, and then we can call it even. ...Oh, and sorry for that whole  'I'm gonna kill you thing' earlier.＂
The woman brought Marishiten to her castle only to find it surrounded by enemies. She bemoaned how fate had tricked her at such a late date, but the dragon only smiled.
Roaring with delight, Marishiten raged across the battlefield and hewed the enemy soldiers like grain. Before the day was out, not a single one was left standing.
The woman's country was saved. She praised Marishiten's strength— naming her the dragon of battle— and swore to pass word of her fury and honor through the generations.
But how did her descendants pledge their souls to Marishiten and become known as the Twelve Wyrmclans? Alas, that is a story for another day.
